componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to CenturyLink's Fourth Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Tony Davis, Vice President of Investor Relations. Mr. Davis, you may begin.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, PsyD. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to our call today to discuss CenturyLink's fourth quarter 2010 results released earlier this morning. The slide presentation we will be reviewing during the prepared remarks portion of today's call is a
componenttext:
Thank you, PsyD. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to our call today to discuss CenturyLink's fourth quarter 2010 results released earlier this morning. The slide presentation we will be reviewing during the prepared remarks portion of today's call is available on CenturyLink's IR website at ir.centurylink.com or the Investor Relations section of our corporate website at www.centurylink.com. At the conclusion of our prepared remarks today, we will open the call for Q&A. 
Now turning to Slide 2, Slide 2 contains our Safe Harbor language for your information. We will be making certain forward-looking statements today, particularly as they pertain to guidance for 2011, the Embarq integration and the pending acquisition of Qwest and other outlooks in our business. Please review our Safe Harbor language found in our press release and in our SEC filings, which describe factors that could cause our actual results to differ materially from those projected by us and our forward-looking statements. 
Moving to Slide 3, we asked that you also note that our earnings release issued earlier this morning, and the slide presentation and remarks made during this call contain certain non-GAAP financial measures. Reconciliations between the non-GAAP financial measures and the GAAP financial measures are available in our earnings release and on our website at www.centurylink.com.
Turning to Slide 4, your host for today's call is Glen Post, Chief Executive Officer and President of CenturyLink. Joining Glen on our call today is Stewart Ewing, CenturyLink's Chief Financial Officer. And also available during the question-and-answer period of today's call is Karen Puckett, CenturyLink's Chief Operating Officer. Our call today will be accessible for telephone replay through February 21, 2011, and available for webcast replay through March 7, 2011. For anyone listening to a taped or webcast replay of this call, or for anyone reviewing a written transcript of today's call, please note that all information presented is current only as of February 15, 2011, and should be considered valid only as of this day regardless of the date listened to or reviewed. 
As you turn to Slide 5, I will now turn the call over to your host today, Glen Post. Glen?

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tony. We appreciate you joining us today as we discussed CenturyLink's fourth quarter and full year 2010 operating results, as well as look at operational updates and 2011 guidance information. Now first, we reported solid results for the fourt
componenttext:
Thank you, Tony. We appreciate you joining us today as we discussed CenturyLink's fourth quarter and full year 2010 operating results, as well as look at operational updates and 2011 guidance information. Now first, we reported solid results for the fourth quarter, for full year 2010. We achieved operating revenues in the fourth quarter that exceeded a top end of our guidance, and diluted earnings per share near the top-end of our guidance, operating revenues for full year 2010  were $7.04 billion, representing ayear-over-year increase of 41.6%, primarily driven by the mid-2009 acquisition of Embarq along with continued growth and strategic revenues. Second, we achieved solid high-speed Internet subscriber additions during the fourth quarter and full year 2010 resulting in an annual subscriber growth rate of more than 7%. Additionally, we improved our access line to climb of more than 20% full year 2010 compared to pro forma full-year 2009. We also continued the expansion of our Prism, our IPTV service and we're expanding our Internet profit line across our footprint to better serve our business and wholesale customers. Now the integration of the Embarq continues to proceed well and we continued to make good progress towards completing the pending Qwest transaction.
Now moving to Slide 6 and the debt. Operating revenues were $1.72 billion for the quarter, slightly ahead of the $1.71 billion at the top end of our guidance. Diluted earnings per share, excluding nonrecurring items, were $0.76 per share, $0.01 lower than street consensus according to first call. Our cash flows remained strong as we generated free cash flow of $342 million in the fourth quarter, excluding $9.1 million of capital investment related to the Embarq integration. Additionally, we achieved approximately $85 million of total operating expense synergies associated with the Embarq integration during the fourth quarter and ended the year with annual run rate synergies of $340 million.
There were a few factors that contribute to our operating revenues exceeding the top end of our previous guidance for the quarter. First, we lost fewer access lines that we had forecast for the quarter. Second, our access benefit use declined at a slower rate than we had anticipated for the quarter. And finally, we had a couple of prior period true ups that positively impacted revenue. There were also a few expense items that were higher than we had anticipated for the quarter. First, we incurred higher pull rental expenses than anticipated either is seasonal and cost adjustments under certain contracts. And second, we incurred higher contract labor and overtime charges than expected, driven by the expansion of our IPTV service, weather impacts and conversion initiatives.
Demand for our strategic products and services continues to grow and the strategic revenues are increasing as a percentage of total operating revenues. In the fourth quarter 2010 strategic revenues accounted for 31% of revenues compared to 28% in the fourth quarter of 2009.
The growth in strategic revenues represent the total operating revenue as a positive trend that we are focused on continuing, in which we expect to realize on revenues from reduced revenues from traditional legacy and access sources. We remain focused on the positioning CenturyLink as a relevant provider of choice in our markets and we continued to enhance our broadband product portfolio to deploy higher speeds in key markets, as well adding incremental value through figure and computer support and online backup services.
Also, we continued to enhance and expand our advanced of the data in IP networks and value-added services for our business and enterprise customers.
Now turning to Slide 7. I'd Like to cover a few operating highlights for the quarter. First, we'd added nearly 29,000 high-speed Internet customers during the quarter as the demand for broadband remains solid and customers have continued to respond well to our broadband offers. We ended the quarter with approximately 2.4 million as our customers or 42.1% penetration of our broadband enabled access lines and approximately 38.5% penetration of total addressable access lines. We were pleased that we're able to add more than 158,000 high-speed Internet customers during 2010, representing approximately 7.1% year-over-year growth and total high-speed Internet subscribers. In addition, we experienced lower access line losses during the quarter than we had previously anticipated. Our fourth quarter line loss of approximately 123,000 represents a 12% sequential improvement over Q4 2010 and a 15.8% improvement over the fourth quarter 2009 access line loss. We continued to see a decline in outs and disconnect orders in both the Consumer and Business segments which we believe is attributable to a more stable economy, are resulting in fewer moves, less business line downsizing and fewer competitive ports.
We're pleased we have been successful in reducing our rate of line loss for the trailing 12 months ended December 31, 2010, to 7.6% compared to a pro forma 8.8% treading 12 months line loss a year ago. One of the keys to this ongoing improvement in customer loss has been the performance of the top five Embarq markets. We continued to see strong tracks in these markets and improvement continued to outpace the rest of the company. We also continued to strengthen our competitive position with partnerships, new product launches and continued execution. This morning, we announced our agreement Verizon wireless to offer a Verizon wireless equipment and service plans to small and residential customers. We're looking forward later this year offering a complete product bundle to improve the leverage to all of our customer base.
Our business for selling DIRECTV are now fully implemented and we're seeing strong results adding nearly 40,000 satellite video subscribers in the fourth quarter. We ended 2010 with almost 628,000 satellite video customers. We also currently offer our CenturyLink Prizm service in five markets across Wisconsin, and Columbia and Jefferson City, Missouri. Our newest markets are Las Vegas, Nevada and Fort Myers, Naples, Florida. We've exceeded our internal forecast for customer net gains this past year and we are pleased with the progress we're making with our Prism TV service thus far.
The number of Prism capable households past increased more than 60% in the fourth quarter and we continued to expect the past close to 1 million households by the end of this year. We continued to expect to rollout Prism TV service in three additional markets in 2011, bringing CenturyLink's Prism TV to a total of eight markets. In our Enterprise segment, we lost enhanced and our providing and PLS VIP on pricing in a number of key markets. In our Enterprise segment, we expand our NPLS reach by completing wholesale agreement with Qwest and added key value-added capabilities to our ethernet products set. This set provide larger in multiple and PLS sales particularly to a larger delta care and regional banking sectors. Our operating model with global sales and operations depth, now coupled with national data capabilities is enhancing your position in IP data network opportunities.
Now turning to Slide 8. We continued to face a number of challenges during the quarter including very competitive marketplace, the high unemployment and the economy and all of the Embarq integration and pending Qwest merging planning activities we have in process. However, we continued to generate strong cash flows for full year 2010. Our operating cash flow, excluding nonrecurring items, was approximately $3.62 billion in 2010. Our full-year total debt and free cash flow was nearly $1.63 billion. Our strong cash flows continues to support the return of cash to shareholders. We paid $220 million in dividends to shareholders during the fourth quarter, and $878 million of dividends during the full year of 2010. Our strong cash flows support the continued payment of dividends to shareholders and our 54% payout ratio continues to be one of the lowest in our industry.
Turning to Slide 9. We continued to make great progress towards completing the integration of Embarq. Our fourth market conversion which in the customers in the state of Florida it is scheduled to occur by the end of the first quarter. We also remain on schedule to complete the fifth and final Embarq customer billing conversion by the end of third quarter of this year. We have completed the migration of the Embarq long-distance customers, representing 400 million minutes of use per month to the CenturyLink IP network, which eliminates, of course, third-party costs for the company. And we continued to see improvement in the urban market operating results and we're consistently meeting our synergy targets, so we're extremely pleased with the Embarq integration.
Now moving to Slide 10. We continued to move steadily ahead with the approval process in the integration planning work for our pending acquisition of Qwest. To date, we received 18 of the 22 regulatory commission approvals required to complete the merger. We continued to work with the remaining four regulatory commissions and the Federal Communications Commission, our remaining approvals. While it is difficult to predict the timing of these remaining regulatory approvals, we currently expect to receive all required regulatory approvals by the end of the first quarter. Therefore, we are currently planning for an April 1, 2011, close and the launch of our combined company. Of course, we do not control the regulatory process and therefore, the close date could be moved out if need to the remaining approvals take longer than we currently anticipate. We continued to make good progress in the organization, design, and planning of the many integration activities required to integrate the two companies, organization design is complete, the employee selection is now underway and we should be substantially complete with those in the next few weeks.
At this time, I'll turn the call over to Stewart for additional financial highlights and review of our 2011 guidance. Stewart?

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Glen. During the next few minutes, I'll review some of the highlights of our fourth quarter 2010 operating results and I will conclude my comments with the discussion of the 2011 guidance provided in our earnings release issued earlier today.
componenttext:
Thank you, Glen. During the next few minutes, I'll review some of the highlights of our fourth quarter 2010 operating results and I will conclude my comments with the discussion of the 2011 guidance provided in our earnings release issued earlier today.
Turning to Slide 12. I want to begin by reviewing with you a few significant nonrecurring items that occurred during the fourth quarter, and then I will discuss the fourth quarter normalized results. First, we incurred approximately $27.2 million of pretax expenses or about $0.05 per share related to the integration and severance costs associated with the Embarq integration. Second, we incurred about $7.1 million in pretax transaction, and integration costs are about $0.02 per share related to the pending Qwest acquisition. Third, we had a pretax curtailment gain of $20.9 million or a $0.04 per share associated with freezing our defined benefit pension plan and related to future accruals. Last, we had other net tax benefits that collectively amounted to about $0.01 a share. In the aggregate, these items represent the $0.02 per share difference, and normalized diluted earnings per share of $0.76 and GAAP diluted earnings per share of $0.74.
Turning to Slide 13. This slide reflects our results for fourth quarter 2010 compared to fourth quarter 2009, excluding nonrecurring items for both periods as outlined in our financial schedules. For fourth quarter 2010, operating revenues decreased $118 million to $1.72 billion from $1.84 billion in fourth quarter a year ago. Our cash operating expenses decreased $38 million from $895 million in fourth quarter 2009 to $857 million in fourth quarter 2010, primarily due to synergies achieved from the Embarq integration. Depreciation and amortize expense increased from $356 million in fourth quarter 2009 to $365 million in fourth quarter 2010, primarily due to depreciation associated with the increased plant and service that more than offset the decline in amortization under the declining balance method for our Embarq intangibles.
Net income attributable to CenturyLink for the quarter was $232 million compared to $287 million in fourth quarter 2009. And diluted earnings per share for the quarter decreased to $0.76 from $0.95 in the fourth quarter a year ago. The percentage decline in net income is higher than the percentage decline in operating cash flow due primarily to the smaller denominator.
This year-over-year decrease in net income and earnings per share is due to the anticipated revenue declines we've discussed with you throughout this year, and the challenge of reducing cost in the near term due to the pending Qwest merger and the expansion of IP TV service to additional markets. Completing the successful integration of Embarq and planning for and achieving a successful integration of the pending Qwest merger are two of our primary focus areas. Additionally, we are incurring startup expenses as we expand offering of our IP TV service to additional markets and as we expand our high-bandwidth service offerings to enterprise customers. While the merger integrations in these product expansions impact our operating costs in the near term, we are confident that these represent investments in the future success and growth of CenturyLink.
Finally, our free cash flow increased 2.5% from nearly $334 million in fourth quarter 2009 to $342 million in fourth quarter 2010 due to lower capital expenditures in the quarter.
Moving to Slide 14. I would like to discuss our 2010 results compared to our previous full year 2010 guidance. First, operating revenues declined by 6.5% in 2010 compared to pro forma 2009 operating revenues compared to our previous guidance of an anticipated full year revenue decline of 6.5% to 7%. Second, we generated $1.6 billion of free cash flow for 2010 compared to our previous guidance of $1.58 billion to $1.62 billion. From a diluted earnings per share standpoint to $3.39 per share we achieved for full year 2010 is that the high-end of our latest guidance of $3.36 to $3.46 per share. Finally, we invested $864 million in capital expenditures in 2010, which is within our prior guidance of $825 million to  to $875 million. The capital that we invested in 2010 included the enablement of high-speed Internet service, IPTV in several markets, expansion of ethernet availability and fiber to the tower. Our 2011 capital investments will continue to focus on these areas which will enable future growth.
Now turning to Slide 20. Our 2011 guidance excludes the effects of nonrecurring items, integration expenses associated with the Embarq acquisition, transaction and integration expenses associated with the pending Qwest transaction, any changes in operating or capital plans, any changes in regulation and any future mergers, acquisitions, divestitures or other similar business transactions. For full-year 2011, CenturyLink expects operating revenues to be 4% to 5% lower than 2010 operating revenues, as revenue increases associated with the growth in and Internet are expected to be more than offset by revenue declines associated with lower access revenues, reduced Universal Service Funding, access line losses and other items. Additionally, due to anticipated revenue growth associated with the expansion of CenturyLink's Prism TV service, the revenue impact of the expected continued improvement in the rate of access line loss and the effects of additional fiber investment, we expect the year-over-year rate of revenue declines, excluding the Qwest transaction and any other nonrecurring items that may occur, to be in the 2% to 4% range by fourth quarter 2011. The company currently expects 2011 capital expenditures to be approximately $1 billion or 16% higher than 2010 capital expenditures of $864 million, the increase is primarily due to planned incremental fiber to the tower investment.
We expect the Qwest transaction to close on April 1, therefore, we're not providing full year 2011 free cash flow earnings per share guidance. However, we are providing guidance regarding several items that collectively are expected to negatively impact 2011 diluted earnings per share by $0.49 to $0.55.
Items that are anticipated to positively impact 2011 diluted earnings per share are expected synergies associated with the Embarq acquisition in the $0.09 to $0.11 range; increased revenues associated with the expected growth in high-speed Internet customers, $0.10 to $0.14 per share; increased revenues associated with data transport for loss carriers, $0.06 to $0.08 per share; and anticipated lower interest expense in the range of $0.05 to $0.07 per share. The following items are expected to negatively impact 2011 diluted earnings per share. Lower voice-related revenues primarily due to anticipated access line losses of 7% to 7.5%, in the range of $0.40 to $0.45 per share; lower access revenues primarily driven by access line losses and continued pressure on access minutes of use, $0.18 to $0.22 per share; start up losses associated with the expansion of CenturyLink's Prism TV service, $0.12 to $0.14 a share; reduced interstate Universal Service Funding $0.05 to $0.06 per share; and expected migration of network traffic from wireless carrier customer, $0.05 to $0.07 per share.
For the first quarter 2011, CenturyLink expects total revenues of $1.68 billion to $1.7 billion and diluted earnings per share of $0.66 to $0.70. The decline in first quarter diluted earnings per share compared to fourth quarter is primarily due to continued decline in access lines, access minutes, the normal annual adjustment to USF revenue, increased payroll taxes and the continued expansion of IPTV.
Now turning to Slide 16. Finally, as we outlined in our press release this morning, there are several items that I want to briefly discuss regarding the accounting rules for business combinations that you would want to consider when building a financial model for the combination of CenturyLink and Qwest. None of these items will impact cash flow.
First, purchase accounting rules require that the debt of Qwest be adjusted to fair value at the time of the merger closed. Based on Qwest's outstanding debt as of December 31, 2010, the impact of this fair value adjustment would have decreased interest expense for pro forma full-year 2011 by approximately $287 million compared to the expected levels absent the fair value adjustment.
Second, deferred revenues and related deferred costs from Qwest's balance sheet must be assigned a fair value. We currently anticipate the fair value of the deferred revenues and related costs to be assigned minimal to no value. Therefore, as of December 31, 2010, we estimate that pro forma 2011 revenues would have been negatively impacted by approximately $140 million and that pro forma 2011 operating expenses would be reduced by approximately $100 million.
Third, the tangible and intangible assets of Qwest must be reflected on the books of the combined company at their fair value. The fair value assignment may significantly impact depreciation and amortization of the customer base. However, the impact cannot be determined at this time. Finally, the merger will result in the elimination of approximately $70 million of annual revenues and corresponding expenses related to arms length business relationships between CenturyLink and Qwest today that will become intercompany transactions and subject to elimination following the merger close.
So this concludes our prepared remarks for today. At this time, I'll ask the operator to provide further instructions for the question-and-answer portion of our call.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Dave Coleman, RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Dave Coleman, RBC Capital Markets.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just A couple of questions. Glen, I believe you mentioned that in the fourth quarter, there was higher over time and labor expenses. Can you just quantify how much that impacted for 4Q SG&A and I believe that's where the allocated. And then secondly, your
componenttext: Just A couple of questions. Glen, I believe you mentioned that in the fourth quarter, there was higher over time and labor expenses. Can you just quantify how much that impacted for 4Q SG&A and I believe that's where the allocated. And then secondly, your revenue guidance for 2011 implies about a $30 million step down in the first quarter from 4Q 2010, but an equivalent amount declined over the subsequent three quarters. So I was just hoping you would be able to walk through the items that will cause that change in revenue trajectory through 2011. And then final question, you outlined a number of items that will impact 2011 EPS versus 2010. That $0.49 to $0.55 adjustment or impact to 2011 EPS, how much of that will you say as a continuation of 2010 run rates versus new items in 2011?

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'll take the first one and that Stewart can take the last. Regarding the fourth quarter that was about $10 million impact in the quarter from those expenses. And Stewart, you want to talk about the revenue guidance?
componenttext: I'll take the first one and that Stewart can take the last. Regarding the fourth quarter that was about $10 million impact in the quarter from those expenses. And Stewart, you want to talk about the revenue guidance?

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: In terms of the revenue guidance, the $30 million decline that we anticipate in the first quarter compared with the fourth quarter, about $7 million of it relates to the decline in Universal Service Fund receipts that we received, which, again, is related
componenttext: In terms of the revenue guidance, the $30 million decline that we anticipate in the first quarter compared with the fourth quarter, about $7 million of it relates to the decline in Universal Service Fund receipts that we received, which, again, is related to the normal adjustment that's made in the first of each year based on the nationwide average local. We additionally in terms of long distance declines in revenue, as well as network access and just basic voice revenue, is about $15 million or so from the fourth quarter to the first quarter. So that makes up the majority of the declines on which that from the fourth to first. And then 2011 versus '10, the EPS items in terms of how much is a continuation, basically, the items that impact the decline in revenues related to access line declines and minutes of use basically are items that do just continue from 2010 to 2011. I mean, we'll continue to see declines in those items. They are new declines, they're not just variables basically. So there's really not very much in terms of carryover. There are a few items in terms of the wireless carrier that's migrating traffic, also the Embarq network, as well as some database lookup revenue that Embarq had, and that's probably in the neighborhood combined about $15 million or so, $15 million to $20 million.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: But could we also get the one-time revenue contributor to the fourth quarter? And also, just again with respect to that first quarter guidance, it seems like if you do the math on the earnings versus the revenue change, it seems like more than 100% of the
componenttext: But could we also get the one-time revenue contributor to the fourth quarter? And also, just again with respect to that first quarter guidance, it seems like if you do the math on the earnings versus the revenue change, it seems like more than 100% of the revenue change is dropping down to the pretax line. So not only is all the revenue dropping out of the EBITDA line, but more. So could you kind of help us understand what's going on here? I'm not sure we've seen ever more than 100% of the revenue come out of the company in a single quarter of this magnitude. And then the second question was just related to the tower fiber investment, which is a big incremental step up, a big investment on your part, presumably it's not a speculative investment. Could you kind of give us some more details about the economics around the returns on that money?

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me get to the second question first. The first quarter to the fourth quarter, basically, the further decline in EBITDA is really due to expense increases that we'll see in the first quarter. One, we have about $10 million of increase costs associ
componenttext: Yes, let me get to the second question first. The first quarter to the fourth quarter, basically, the further decline in EBITDA is really due to expense increases that we'll see in the first quarter. One, we have about $10 million of increase costs associated with payroll taxes, basically starting over at the beginning of the year. And then secondly, we have some additional costs, probably about $10 million of an increase, fourth to first related to the continued rollout of the IPTV service. In terms of one-time revenue items to the first quarter, we had about $8 million of positive adjustments in total in the fourth quarter. Glen on the fiber to the sell investment, but these are not speculative investments and virtually, all of these investments will have five to seven year, mostly seven-year contracts on these guarantee our revenue streams and our returns for the time basically.

componenttext: I want to follow on the guidance question. I believe your outlook for revenue decline especially the 2% to 3% decline by your income it's very non-what the street is looking for. When we put that along with the number of items you added that will hit EPS by about $0.60, you could sort of back out into what margins we could see and it looks like we have seen the peak in the third quarter and it's starting to trend lower to below 50%, do you think this is a conservative guidance or are there more cost cutting opportunities that could drive them higher? And a second question I had on the broadband side. It looks like you expect broadband to be a larger contributor of earnings in '11 versus '10. But broadband and net adds have looked like they have stabilized. So can you talk about the pricing environment you're seeing there and maybe some sense of what speeds customers are taking?

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, Batya, I guess the first thing, the guidance will all change next quarter once we're combined with Qwest and we start folding in synergies associated with Qwest. I would say, though that the margins really continued to decline somewhat due to the con
componenttext: Yes, Batya, I guess the first thing, the guidance will all change next quarter once we're combined with Qwest and we start folding in synergies associated with Qwest. I would say, though that the margins really continued to decline somewhat due to the continued rollout of IPTV primarily during the rest of the year, the remainder of the year just on a stand-alone basis.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: I might add, too, on the expense side that impact EPS, with the anticipation of the Qwest transaction, we have not made cuts in costs that we would have normally, and that is having an impact, a significant impact on our expense levels. So as we bring com
componenttext: I might add, too, on the expense side that impact EPS, with the anticipation of the Qwest transaction, we have not made cuts in costs that we would have normally, and that is having an impact, a significant impact on our expense levels. So as we bring companies together, we'll see back to more businesses as usual over the next coming months and our costs synergy will be in line over time with our revenues.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011

Any sense of what the timing looks like, and any cost from implementing that? And then, you've had a couple of days to look through the NPR from the FCC, any updated thoughts on the U.S. and to carrier comp proposals?

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: First of all, Simon, the Verizon deal is similar to the Qwest transaction. We'll be able to sell all the products and services, basically all the platforms we think it's going to really enhance our ability to bring a full array of products a full bundle t
componenttext:
First of all, Simon, the Verizon deal is similar to the Qwest transaction. We'll be able to sell all the products and services, basically all the platforms we think it's going to really enhance our ability to bring a full array of products a full bundle to our customers including wireless. As far as the cost, the cost we'll incur are primarily system costs overtime, we bring the building and begin to bill the wireless portion of the bill. But other than that, there are not a lot of costs other than just training costs for employee base where we have a cost that incurred there. As for timing, we expect to begin selling the service in the next few months. In the next couple of months, we should roll it out and of course expanding that for the rest of the year. Regarding the proposed NPRM, the FCC released last week really as the national broadband plan. It presents some opportunities and risks for CenturyLink and our real customers of course. We need room in the NPRM it's just the starting point. It's not an order, so there's much work to be done within the industry to build overall consensus around reform, obviously, the details and the matters of agency off really implements and reform will be critical. We continue to support our approach and includes a reasonable transition period, minimum customer rate increases and no unintended mandates. And we believe there are really a combined company with Qwest will be well-positioned to manage any of the performance that may eventually be enacted.
As you know, the NPRM propose to reduce access charges over time. But it also propose a stabilized the transition by harmonizing rates, reducing overcharge, minimizing disputes. It also proposes to create an offsetting revenue opportunity, provide access to UFS support where it's needed from data high speed data so we expect a pretty consistent process here, and although we certainly starting, as well as we could expect at this point.

And with regards to the Verizon Wireless transaction, any deal there to at least some of your 700 megahertz spectrum or what are the thoughts on utilization of that asset?

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: As far as enterprise trends, we are seeing business start to spend more. We're not seeing a lot of new startups in the smaller midsized business area. But businesses are beginning to spend more. We hope that we will see that continue, and expanded in the
componenttext: As far as enterprise trends, we are seeing business start to spend more. We're not seeing a lot of new startups in the smaller midsized business area. But businesses are beginning to spend more. We hope that we will see that continue, and expanded in the months ahead. Our outlook, by the way, does not include a real change in the economy. and the one thing we're doing is we believe are positioning the company to really take advantage of opportunities as the economy changes there. But over time, with the Qwest acquisition, especially with the enterprise, it's a real opportunity for us as far as future growth and establishing CenturyLink as a really nationwide enterprise company. As far as the Verizon deal, we don't really have anything there to utilize our 7 megahertz there, it's not at this point. We our 700 megahertz will represent with the Qwest small percentage of our total footprint, but we will begin some trials later this year. We're going to be a thought fast forward to AT&T and Verizon on the 7 megahertz technology. It's still not where it needs to be is for us we're concerned anyway, what will be doing some trial is there and it is obviously an attractive service. And it's a possibility that we can work with one of the company's overtime to build out and to share spectrum in some way. But that's a work in progress.

componenttext: On the wireless front,how many years do you think it'll take to build out the most of the towers in your territory? And I guess are you concerned at all or concerns on wireless cannibalization at this point with your LTE speeds you could be up around the 10 megabit kind of range? And I guess if you guys or essentially enabling them to roll earlier is what's to prevent that from cannibalizing the existing wireline broadband that you have out there now? And I guess related to that, maybe you could just give an update where your broadband speeds are now for wireline and kind of where you that can go?

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: First of all, the build out within the next year and a half, we should have virtually the best and the build out complete and kind of ongoing. So but midyear next year, we should be pretty well, the vast majority in most of it. But financial year and a ha
componenttext: First of all, the build out within the next year and a half, we should have virtually the best and the build out complete and kind of ongoing. So but midyear next year, we should be pretty well, the vast majority in most of it. But financial year and a half most have it done. With broadband substitution, our LTE, we don't think there'll be some of that. We're not really concerned with that as much because just the demand on the carrier network for the wireless data growth, it's, I don't think they would want to pick up on the wireline data that's out there. I think customers are very satisfied with the wireline speeds they have. The pricing is competitive. So we don't have any real concerns on a broad scale but we'll see a lot of cannibalization by LTE in our networks. And our average speeds are about five meg, I think across the company, and that's kind of what we're feeling average for us usage.

componenttext: Well, we don't want to talk about headcount but I can tell you that cost we realized in the cost of the business as usual is when you see access revenues, U.S. sales revenues coming down. We have to match our costs with the revenue decline. So we are very cognizant of those requirements and as we work through the Qwest transaction and the synergies there, we'll actually required to really match our cost of where our revenue potentially. We'll increase some investments and spend headcount in some areas. But at the same time, we'll reduce headcount and costs in areas where we're seeing reduced revenue. So that's always on our agenda here.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: In closing, CenturyLink continued to build on our solid results we've achieved in the last years and since closing the Embarq transaction we achieved solid results in the fourth quarter 2010 as we continue to slow the year-over-year rate of access line lo
componenttext:
In closing, CenturyLink continued to build on our solid results we've achieved in the last years and since closing the Embarq transaction we achieved solid results in the fourth quarter 2010 as we continue to slow the year-over-year rate of access line losses, drive revenue growth from strategic product and services, our local operating model combined with our strong product portfolio and target marketing efforts continued to be effective in driving results. Also, our employees continued to do an outstanding job of serving our customers while some simultaneously integrating Embarq operations into our company and preparing for the Qwest acquisition integration. We're going to Qwest transaction approval process and planning for the Qwest integration are going well and I'm very confident in our company's ability to execute our business plan in the months ahead.
Thank you for participating on our call today. We really look forward to speaking with you again in the near future.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to CenturyLink's Fourth Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Tony Davis, Vice President of Investor Relations. Mr. Davis, you may beg
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to CenturyLink's Fourth Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Tony Davis, Vice President of Investor Relations. Mr. Davis, you may begin.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Saheed. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to our call today to discuss CenturyLink's Fourth Quarter 2010 Results released earlier this morning. The slide presentation we will be reviewing during the prepared remarks portion of today's call is
componenttext:
Thank you, Saheed. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to our call today to discuss CenturyLink's Fourth Quarter 2010 Results released earlier this morning. The slide presentation we will be reviewing during the prepared remarks portion of today's call is available on CenturyLink's IR website at ir.centurylink.com or the Investor Relations section of our corporate website at www.centurylink.com. At the conclusion of our prepared remarks today, we will open the call for Q&A. 
Now turning to Slide 2, Slide 2 contains our Safe Harbor language for your information. We will be making certain forward-looking statements today, particularly as they pertain to guidance for 2011, the Embarq integration and the pending acquisition of Qwest and other outlooks in our business. Please review our Safe Harbor language found in our press release and in our SEC filings, which describe factors that could cause our actual results to differ materially from those projected by us and our forward-looking statements. 
Moving to Slide 3, we asked that you also note that our earnings release issued earlier this morning, and the slide presentation and remarks made during this call contain certain non-GAAP financial measures. Reconciliations between the non-GAAP financial measures and the GAAP financial measures are available in our earnings release and on our website at www.centurylink.com.
Turning to Slide 4, your host for today's call is Glen Post, Chief Executive Officer and President of CenturyLink. Joining Glen on our call today is Stewart Ewing, CenturyLink's Chief Financial Officer. And also available during the question-and-answer period of today's call is Karen Puckett, CenturyLink's Chief Operating Officer. Our call today will be accessible for telephone replay through February 21, 2011, and accessible for webcast replay through March 7, 2011. For anyone listening to a taped or webcast replay of this call, or for anyone reviewing a written transcript of today's call, please note that all information presented is current only as of February 15, 2011, and should be considered valid only as of this date regardless of the date listened to or reviewed. 
As you turn to Slide 5, I will now turn the call over to your host today, Glen Post. Glen?

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tony. We appreciate you joining us today as we discussed CenturyLink's Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2010 Operating Results, as well as selected operational updates and 2011 guidance information. Now first, we reported solid results for the four
componenttext:
Thank you, Tony. We appreciate you joining us today as we discussed CenturyLink's Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2010 Operating Results, as well as selected operational updates and 2011 guidance information. Now first, we reported solid results for the fourth quarter, for full year 2010. We achieved operating revenues in the fourth quarter that exceeded the top end of our guidance, and diluted earnings per share near the top end of our guidance, operating revenues for full year 2010 were $7.04 billion, representing a year-over-year increase of 41.6%, primarily driven by the mid-2009 acquisition of Embarq along with the continued growth and strategic revenues. 
Second, we achieved solid high-speed Internet subscriber additions during the fourth quarter and full year 2010 resulting in an annual subscriber growth rate of more than 7%. Additionally, we improved our absolute access line to climb of more than 20% full year 2010 compared to pro forma full-year of 2009. 
We also continued the expansion of our Prism, our IPTV service and we're expanding our Internet profit line service across our footprint to better serve our business and wholesale customers. Now the integration of the Embarq continues to proceed well and we continued to make good progress towards completing the pending Qwest transaction.
Now moving to Slide 6 and the debt. Operating revenues were $1.72 billion for the quarter, slightly ahead of the $1.71 billion at the top end of our guidance. Diluted earnings per share, excluding nonrecurring items, were $0.76 per share, a $0.01 lower than Street consensus according to first call. 
Our cash flows remained strong as we generated free cash flow of $342 million in the fourth quarter, excluding $9.1 million of capital investment related to the Embarq integration. Additionally, we achieved approximately $85 million of total operating expense synergies associated with the Embarq integration during the fourth quarter and ended the year with annual run rate synergies of $340 million.
There were a few factors that contributed to our operating revenues exceeding the top end of our previous guidance for the quarter. First, we lost fewer access lines that we had forecast for the quarter. Second, our access benefit use declined at a slower rate than we had anticipated for the quarter. And finally, we had a couple of prior period true ups that positively impacted revenue. There were also a few expense items that were higher than we had anticipated for the quarter. First, we incurred higher pull rental expenses than anticipated either it's seasonal and cost adjustments under certain contracts. And second, we incurred higher contract labor and overtime charges than expected, driven by the expansion of our IPTV service, weather impacts and conversion initiatives.
Demand for our strategic products and services continues to grow and the strategic revenues are increasing as a percentage of total operating revenues. In the fourth quarter 2010 strategic revenues accounted for 31% of revenues compared to 28% in the fourth quarter of 2009.
The growth in strategic revenues represent the total operating revenue as a positive trend that we are focused on continuing, in which we expect to realize on revenues from reduced reliance on revenues from traditional legacy and access sources. We remained focused on the positioning of CenturyLink as a relevant provider of choice in our markets and we continued to enhance our broadband product portfolio to deploy higher speeds in key markets, as well as adding incremental value through broadband figures and just computer support and online backup services.
Also, we continued to enhance and expand our advanced data in IP networks and value-added services for our business and enterprise customers.
Now turning to Slide 7. I'd like to cover a few operating highlights for the quarter. First, we'd added nearly 29,000 high-speed Internet customers during the quarter as the demand for broadband remains solid and customers have continued to respond well to our broadband offers. We ended the quarter with approximately 2.4 million access for our customers or 42.1% penetration of our broadband-enabled access lines and approximately 38.5% penetration of total addressable access lines. 
We were pleased that we're able to add more than 158,000 high-speed Internet customers during 2010, representing approximately 7.1% year-over-year growth in total high-speed Internet subscribers. In addition, we experienced lower access line losses during the quarter than we had previously anticipated. Our fourth quarter line loss of approximately 123,000 represents a 12% sequential improvement over third quarter 2010 and a 15.8% improvement over the fourth quarter 2009 access line loss. We continued to see a decline in outs and disconnect orders in both the Consumer and Business segments which we believe is attributable to a more stable economy, are resulting in fewer moves, less business line downsizing and fewer competitive ports.
We're pleased we have been successful in reducing our rate of line loss for the trailing 12 months ended December 31, 2010, to 7.6% compared to a pro forma 8.8% trailing 12 months line loss a year ago. One of the keys to this ongoing improvement in customer loss has been the performance of the top five Embarq markets. We continue to see strong tracks in these markets and improvement then continued to outpace the rest of the company. 
We also continued to strengthen our competitive position with partnerships, new product launches and continued execution. This morning, we announced our agreement with Verizon wireless to offer a Verizon wireless equipment and service plans to our residential and small business customers. We're looking forward later this year offering a complete product bundle to our -- including wireless to all of our customer base.
Our processes for selling DIRECTV are now fully implemented and we're seeing strong results adding nearly 40,000 satellite video subscribers in the fourth quarter. We ended 2010 with almost 628,000 satellite video customers. We also currently offer our CenturyLink Prism service in five markets across Wisconsin, and Columbia and Jefferson City, Missouri. Our newest markets of Las Vegas, Nevada and Fort Myers, Naples, Florida. We've exceeded our internal forecast for customer net gains this past year and we are pleased with the progress we're making with our Prism TV service thus far.
The number of Prism capable households past increased more than 60% in the fourth quarter and we continued to expect the past close to 1 million households by the end of this year. We continued to expect to rollout Prism TV service in three additional markets in 2011, bringing CenturyLink's Prism TV to a total of eight markets. 
In our Enterprise segment, we lost enhanced season net and are providing MPLS VI and PRI it's own pricing in a number of key markets. In our Enterprise segment, we expanded our NPLS reach by completing a wholesale agreement with Qwest and added key value-added capabilities to our ethernet products set. This set provide up to two different larger in multi-site MPLS sales particularly to a larger delta care and regional banking sectors. Our operating model with global sales and operations depth, now coupled with national data capabilities is enhancing our position in IP data network opportunities.
Now turning to Slide 8. We continued to face a number of challenges during the quarter including a very competitive marketplace, the high unemployment economy and all of the Embarq integration and pending Qwest merger planning activities we have in process. However, we continued to generate strong cash flows for full year 2010. Our operating cash flow, excluding nonrecurring items, was approximately $3.62 billion in 2010. Our full-year 2010 free cash flow was nearly $1.63 billion. 
Our strong cash flows continues to support the return of cash to shareholders. We paid $220 million in dividends to shareholders during the fourth quarter, $878 million of dividends during the full year of 2010. Our strong cash flows support the continued payment of dividends to shareholders and our 54% payout ratio continues to be one of the lowest in our industry.
Turning to Slide 9. We continued to make great progress towards completing the integration of Embarq. Our fourth market conversion which is beyond our customers in the state of Florida. It is scheduled to occur by the end of the first quarter. We also remain on schedule to complete the fifth and final Embarq customer billing conversion by the end of third quarter of this year. 
We have completed the migration of Embarq long-distance customers, representing 400 million minutes of use per month to the CenturyLink IP network, which eliminates, of course, third-party carry-on costs for the company. And we continued to see improvement in the urban market operating results and we're consistently meeting our synergy targets, so we're extremely pleased with the Embarq integration.
Now moving to Slide 10. We continued to move steadily ahead with the approval process in the integration planning work for our pending acquisition of Qwest. To date, we received 18 of the 22 regulatory commission approvals required to complete the merger. We continued to work with the remaining four regulatory commissions and the Federal Communications Commission, on the remaining approvals. While it is difficult to predict the timing of these remaining regulatory approvals, we currently expect to receive all required regulatory approvals by the end of the first quarter. 
Therefore, we are currently planning for an April 1, 2011, close and the launch of our combined company. Of course, we do not control the regulatory process and therefore, the close date could be moved out if the remaining approvals take longer than we currently anticipate. We continued to make good progress in the organization design and planning of the many integration activities required to integrate the two companies, organization design is complete, the employee selection is now underway and we should be substantially complete with those in the next few weeks.
At this time, I'll turn the call over to Stewart for additional financial highlights and review of our 2011 guidance. Stewart?

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Glen. During the next few minutes, I'll review some of the highlights of our fourth quarter 2010 operating results and I will conclude my comments with the discussion of the 2011 guidance provided in our earnings release issued earlier today.
componenttext:
Thank you, Glen. During the next few minutes, I'll review some of the highlights of our fourth quarter 2010 operating results and I will conclude my comments with the discussion of the 2011 guidance provided in our earnings release issued earlier today.
Turning to Slide 12. I want to begin by reviewing with you a few significant nonrecurring items that occurred during the fourth quarter, and then I will discuss the fourth quarter normalized results. First, we incurred approximately $27.2 million of pretax expenses or about $0.05 per share related to the integration and severance costs associated with the Embarq integration. Second, we incurred about $7.1 million in pretax transaction, and integration costs are about $0.02 per share related to the pending Qwest acquisition. Third, we had a pretax curtailment gain of $20.9 million or a $0.04 per share associated with freezing our defined benefit pension plan and related to future accruals. Last, we had other net tax benefits that collectively amounted to about $0.01 a share. In the aggregate, these items represent the $0.02 per share difference, and normalized diluted earnings per share of $0.76 and GAAP diluted earnings per share of $0.74.
Turning to Slide 13. This slide reflects our results for fourth quarter 2010 compared to fourth quarter 2009, excluding nonrecurring items for both periods as outlined in our financial schedules. For fourth quarter 2010, operating revenues decreased $118 million to $1.72 billion from $1.84 billion in fourth quarter a year ago. Our cash operating expenses decreased $38 million from $895 million in fourth quarter 2009 to $857 million in fourth quarter 2010, primarily due to synergies achieved from the Embarq integration. Depreciation and amortization expense increased from $356 million in fourth quarter 2009 to $365 million in fourth quarter 2010, primarily due to depreciation associated with the increased plant and service that more than offset the decline in amortization under the declining balance method for our Embarq intangibles.
Net income attributable to CenturyLink for the quarter was $232 million compared to $287 million in fourth quarter 2009. And diluted earnings per share for the quarter decreased to $0.76 from $0.95 in the fourth quarter a year ago. The percentage decline in net income is higher than the percentage decline in operating cash flow due primarily to the smaller denominator.
This year-over-year decrease in net income and earnings per share is due to the anticipated revenue declines we've discussed with you throughout this year, and the challenge of reducing cost in the near term due to the pending Qwest merger and the expansion of IP TV service to additional markets. Completing the successful integration of Embarq and planning for and achieving a successful integration of the pending Qwest merger are two of our primary focus areas. 
Additionally, we are incurring start-up expenses as we expand the offering of our IP TV service to additional markets and as we expand our high-bandwidth service offerings to enterprise customers. While the merger integrations in these product expansions impact our operating costs in the near term, we are confident that these represent investments in the future success and growth of CenturyLink.
Finally, our free cash flow increased 2.5% from nearly $334 million in fourth quarter 2009 to $342 million in fourth quarter 2010 due to lower capital expenditures in the quarter.
Moving to Slide 14. I would like to discuss our 2010 results compared to our previous full year 2010 guidance. First, operating revenues declined by 6.5% in 2010 compared to pro forma 2009 operating revenues compared to our previous guidance of an anticipated full year revenue decline of 6.5% to 7%. Second, we generated $1.6 billion of free cash flow for 2010 compared to our previous guidance of $1.58 billion to $1.62 billion. 
From a diluted earnings per share standpoint to $3.39 per share we achieved for full year 2010 is that the high-end of our latest guidance of $3.36 to $3.46 per share. Finally, we invested $864 million in capital expenditures in 2010, which is within our prior guidance of $825 million to $875 million. The capital that we invested in 2010 included the enablement of high-speed Internet service, IPTV in several markets, expansion of ethernet availability and fiber to the tower. Our 2011 capital investments will continue to focus on these areas which will enable future growth.
Now turning to Slide 20. Our 2011 guidance excludes the effects of nonrecurring items, integration expenses associated with the Embarq acquisition, transaction and integration expenses associated with the pending Qwest transaction, any changes in operating or capital plans, any changes in regulation and any future mergers, acquisitions, divestitures or other similar business transactions. 
For full-year 2011, CenturyLink expects operating revenues to be 4% to 5% lower than 2010 operating revenues, as revenue increases associated with the growth in high speed Internet are expected to be more than offset by revenue declines associated with lower access revenues, reduced Universal Service Funding, access line losses and other items. Additionally, due to anticipated revenue growth associated with the expansion of CenturyLink's Prism TV service, the revenue impact of the expected continued improvement in the rate of access line loss and the effects of additional fiber investment, we expect the year-over-year rate of revenue declines, excluding the Qwest transaction and any other nonrecurring items that may occur, to be in the 2% to 4% range by fourth quarter 2011. The company currently expects 2011 capital expenditures to be approximately $1 billion or 16% higher than 2010 capital expenditures of $864 million, the increase is primarily due to planned incremental fiber to the tower investment.
We expect the Qwest transaction to close on April 1, therefore, we're not providing full year 2011 free cash flow earnings per share guidance. However, we are providing guidance regarding several items that collectively are expected to negatively impact 2011 diluted earnings per share by $0.49 to $0.55.
Items that are anticipated to positively impact 2011 diluted earnings per share are expected synergies associated with the Embarq acquisition in the $0.09 to $0.11 range; increased revenues associated with the expected growth in high-speed Internet customers, $0.10 to $0.14 per share; increased revenues associated with data transport for loss carriers, $0.06 to $0.08 per share; and anticipated lower interest expense in the range of $0.05 to $0.07 per share. The following items are expected to negatively impact 2011 diluted earnings per share. Lower voice-related revenues primarily due to anticipated access line losses of 7% to 7.5%, in the range of $0.40 to $0.45 per share; lower access revenues primarily driven by access line losses and continued pressure on access minutes of use, $0.18 to $0.22 per share; start up losses associated with the expansion of CenturyLink's Prism TV service, $0.12 to $0.14 a share; reduced interstate Universal Service Funding, $0.05 to $0.06 per share; and expected migration of network traffic from a wireless carrier customer, $0.05 to $0.07 per share.
For the first quarter 2011, CenturyLink expects total revenues of $1.68 billion to $1.7 billion and diluted earnings per share of $0.66 to $0.70. The decline in first quarter diluted earnings per share compared to fourth quarter is primarily due to continued decline in access lines, access minutes, the normal annual adjustment to USF revenue, increased payroll taxes and the continued expansion of IPTV.
Now turning to Slide 16. Finally, as we outlined in our press release this morning, there are several items that I want to briefly discuss regarding the accounting rules for business combinations that you would want to consider when building a financial model for the combination of CenturyLink and Qwest. None of these items will impact the cash flow.
First, purchase accounting rules require that the debt of Qwest be adjusted to fair value at the time that the merger closed. Based on Qwest's outstanding debt as of December 31, 2010, the impact of this fair value adjustment would have decreased interest expense for pro forma full-year 2011 by approximately $287 million compared to the expected levels absent the fair value adjustment.
Second, deferred revenues and related deferred costs from Qwest's balance sheet must be assigned a fair value. We currently anticipate the fair value of the deferred revenues and related costs to be assigned minimal to no value. Therefore, as of December 31, 2010, we estimate that pro forma 2011 revenues would have been negatively impacted by approximately $140 million and that pro forma 2011 operating expenses would be reduced by approximately $100 million.
Third, the tangible and intangible assets of Qwest must be reflected on the books of the combined company at their fair value. The fair value assignment may significantly impact depreciation and amortization of the customer base. However, the impact cannot be determined at this time. 
Finally, the merger will result in the elimination of approximately $70 million of annual revenues and corresponding expenses related to arms length business relationships between CenturyLink and Qwest today that will become intercompany transactions and subject to elimination following the merger close.
This concludes our prepared remarks for today. At this time, I'll ask the operator to provide further instructions for the question-and-answer portion of our call.

componenttext: Just a couple of questions. Glen, I believe you mentioned that in the fourth quarter, there was higher over time and labor expenses. Can you just quantify how much that impacted for 4Q SG&A and I believe that's where it'd be allocated. And then secondly, your revenue guidance for 2011 implies about a $30 million step down in the first quarter from 4Q 2010, but an equivalent amount declined over the subsequent three quarters. So I was just hoping you would be able to walk through the items that will cause that change in revenue trajectory through 2011. And then final question, you outlined a number of items that will impact 2011 EPS versus 2010. Of that $0.49 to $0.55 adjustment or impact to 2011 EPS, how much of that would you say is a continuation of 2010 run rates versus new items in 2011?

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: In terms of the revenue guidance, the $30 million decline that we anticipate in the first quarter compared with the fourth quarter, about $7 million of it relates to the decline in Universal Service Fund receipts that we received, which, again, is related
componenttext: In terms of the revenue guidance, the $30 million decline that we anticipate in the first quarter compared with the fourth quarter, about $7 million of it relates to the decline in Universal Service Fund receipts that we received, which, again, is related to the normal adjustment that's made in the first of each year based on the nationwide average cost per local loop. We additionally, in terms of long distance declines in revenue, as well as network access and just basic voice revenue, is about $15 million or so from the fourth quarter to the first quarter. So that makes up the majority of the declines on which the -- from the fourth to first. And then in 2011 versus '10, the EPS items in terms of how much is a continuation, basically, the items that impact the decline in revenues related to access line declines and minutes of use were basically are items that do just continue from 2010 to 2011. I mean, we'll continue to see declines in those items. They are new declines, they're not just variables basically. So there's really not very much in terms of carryover. There are a few items in terms of the wireless carrier that's migrating traffic out of the Embarq network, as well as some database lookup revenue that Embarq had, and that's probably in the neighborhood combined of about $15 million or so, $15 million to $20 million.

componenttext: Yes, let me get to the second question first. One, we have about $10 million of increase costs associated with payroll taxes, basically starting over at the beginning of the year. And then secondly, we have some additional costs, probably about $10 million of an increase, fourth to first related to the continued rollout of the IPTV service. In terms of one-time revenue items to the first quarter, we had about $8 million of positive adjustments in total in the fourth quarter.

componenttext: Dave, this is Glen. componenttext: In terms of -- as Glen said on the churn, it's a 400 basis point kind of improvement we continue to see there. Attachment rate in the 9% range. headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011

componenttext: I wondered if you could just touch on the deal with Verizon Wireless. Is it a similar deal to the one that Qwest has already? Any sense of what the timing looks like, and any cost from implementing that? And then, you've had a couple of days to look through the MPRMs from the FCC, any updated thoughts on the U.S. acting at the carrier comp proposals?

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: First of all, Simon, the Verizon deal is similar to the Qwest transaction. We'll be able to sell all the products and services, basically all the platforms we think it's going to really enhance our ability to bring a full array of products, a full bundle
componenttext:
First of all, Simon, the Verizon deal is similar to the Qwest transaction. We'll be able to sell all the products and services, basically all the platforms we think it's going to really enhance our ability to bring a full array of products, a full bundle to our customers including wireless. As far as the cost, the cost we'll incur are primarily system costs overtime, we bring the building and begin to bill the wireless portion of the bill. But other than that, there are not a lot of costs other than just training costs for employee base where we have a cost that was incurred there. As far as timing, we expect to begin selling the service in the next few months. In the next couple of months, we should roll it out and of course expanding that over for the rest of the year. Regarding the proposed NPRM, the FCC released last week really a poll of the national broadband plan. It prevents longevity and  risks for CenturyLink and our real customers of course. We need room in the NPRM it's just the starting point. It's not an order, so there's much work to be done within the industry to build overall consensus around reform, obviously, the details and the matters of which the off-knowing really implements and reform will be critical. We continue to support our approach and includes a reasonable transition period, minimum customer rate increases and no unfunded mandates. And we believe there are really a combined company with Qwest will be well-positioned to manage any of the performance that may eventually be enacted.
As you know, the NPRM propose to reduce access charges over time. But it also propose a stabilized of disease transition by harmonizing rates, reducing arbitrage, minimizing disputes. It also proposes to create an offsetting revenue opportunity, provide access to UFS support where it's needed from data high speed data. So we expect a pretty consistent process here, and although we certainly as it always we kind of as well as we could expect at this point.

componenttext: Can you give us comments on what the enterprise trends have been? What have you seen in and some of your larger markets, from a business perspective and the outlook for the year there? And with regards to the Verizon Wireless transaction, any deal there to at least some of your 700 megahertz spectrum or what are the thoughts on utilization of that asset?

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: As far as enterprise trends, we are seeing business start to spend more. We're not seeing a lot of new startups in the smaller midsized business area. But businesses are already beginning to spend more. We hope that we will see that continue, and expanded
componenttext: As far as enterprise trends, we are seeing business start to spend more. We're not seeing a lot of new startups in the smaller midsized business area. But businesses are already beginning to spend more. We hope that we will see that continue, and expanded in the months ahead. Our outlook, by the way, does not include a real change in the economy. And one thing we're doing is we believe are positioning our company really take advantage of opportunities it had, the economy changes there. But over time, with the Qwest acquisition, especially with believe the enterprise, it's a real opportunity for us as far as future growth and establishing CenturyLink as a really nationwide enterprise company. As far as the Verizon deal, we don't really have anything there to utilize our 7 megahertz series, it's not at this point. Whereas our 700 megahertz will represent with the Qwest, only a small percentage of our total footprint, but we will begin some trials later this year. We're going to be a fast baller that will hit AT&T and Verizon on the 7 megahertz technology. It's still not where it needs to be but as for us we're concerned anyway. And we'll be doing some trial there and it is obviously a really, an attractive service. And it's a possibility that we can work with one of the company's overtime to build out and to share spectrum in some way. But that's a work in progress.

And then I have a couple of follow-ups.

componenttext: No. I mean, not necessarily. I mean, it really depends on the expense control later in the year and it depends on the revenue. The reducing earnings decline in revenue that we have projected in and expense control basically. The USF, that will pretty much be flat for the year from now, and the same as it is for the fourth quarter.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: On the wireless front, how many years do you think it'll take to build out the most of the towers in your territory? And I guess are you concerned at all or have the increase concerns on wireless cannibalization at this point with your LTE speeds seemed t
componenttext: On the wireless front, how many years do you think it'll take to build out the most of the towers in your territory? And I guess are you concerned at all or have the increase concerns on wireless cannibalization at this point with your LTE speeds seemed to be up around the 10 megabit kind of range? And I guess if you guys are essentially enabling that kind of roll out to the rural areas, what's to prevent that from cannibalizing the existing wireline broadband that you have out there now? And I guess related to that, maybe you could just give us an update where your average broadband speeds are now for wireline and kind of where you think that can go?

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: First of all, the build out within the next year and a half, we should have virtually the best job in the build out complete and kind of ongoing. But midyear next year, we should be pretty well, the vast majority -- and really about the end of this year i
componenttext: First of all, the build out within the next year and a half, we should have virtually the best job in the build out complete and kind of ongoing. But midyear next year, we should be pretty well, the vast majority -- and really about the end of this year is the most of it. But financial year and a half have most of it done. With broadband substitution, our LTE, we don't think there'll be some of that. We're not really concerned with that as much because just the demand on the carrier network for the wireless data growth, it's actually -- I don't think they would want to pick up on the wireline data that's out there. I think customers are very satisfied with the wireline speeds they have. The pricing is competitive. So we don't have any real concerns on a broad scale but we'll see a lot of cannibalization by LTE in our networks. And our average speeds are about five meg, I think across the company, and that's kind of what we're feeling average for us, the usage.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011

componenttext: Our next question comes from Kevin Smith.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, we don't want to talk about headcount but I can tell you that cost we realized in the cost of the business as usual is when you see an access revenues, U.S. sales revenues coming down. We have to match our costs with the revenue decline. So we are v
componenttext: Well, we don't want to talk about headcount but I can tell you that cost we realized in the cost of the business as usual is when you see an access revenues, U.S. sales revenues coming down. We have to match our costs with the revenue decline. So we are very cognizant of those requirements and as we work through the Qwest transaction and the synergies there, we'll actually required to really match our cost of where our revenue potentially. We'll increase some investments and spend headcount in some areas. But at the same time, we'll reduce headcount and costs in areas where we're seeing reduced revenue. So that's always on our agenda here.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 15, 2011
componenttextpreview: In closing, CenturyLink continues to build on our solid results we've achieved in the last years and since closing the Embarq transaction we achieved solid results in the fourth quarter 2010 as we continue to slow the year-over-year rate of access line lo
componenttext:
In closing, CenturyLink continues to build on our solid results we've achieved in the last years and since closing the Embarq transaction we achieved solid results in the fourth quarter 2010 as we continue to slow the year-over-year rate of access line losses, drive revenue growth from the strategic product and services, our local operating model combined with our strong product portfolio and target marketing efforts continued to be effective in driving results. 
Also, our employees continued to do an outstanding job of serving our customers while some simultaneously integrating Embarq operations into our company and preparing for the Qwest acquisition integration, work on the Qwest transaction approval process and planning for the Qwest integration are going well and I'm very confident in our company's ability to execute our business plan in the months ahead.
Thank you for participating on our call today. We really look forward to speaking with you again in the near future.
