headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, Bill, just one other thing on what Karen was saying, just a reminder that our gross sales increased year-over-year on HSI. So it was more of a churn issue as we talked about, a lot of competitive issue most necessarily of the churn issue on a stand-
componenttext: Well, Bill, just one other thing on what Karen was saying, just a reminder that our gross sales increased year-over-year on HSI. So it was more of a churn issue as we talked about, a lot of competitive issue most necessarily of the churn issue on a stand-alone HSI, we expect higher churn and we really thought this would happen from this Qwest markets. Regarding enterprise, enterprise remains steady during the quarter. They actually increased quarter-over-quarter, a little higher in the second quarter than it was at first and sequentially as far as revenues. We believe that the combination is really going strong for with the Qwest, cross selling with Qwest and Savvis. We've already begun customer some great amount of interest in the cloud product and with the Savvis customer in a network capability that CenturyLink brings. So we're very optimistic that we're going to see revenue synergies here. Of course, we have not forecast any of those, but in initial customers, as well as our sales leaders, we are seeing a lot of optimism and what's expected there so I think the combination as we expected, with the network and the cloud products, hosting parts of Savvis brings is going to be very effective.

componenttext: Yes. Just a little follow-up there, the quality of $50 million or so you talked, it's more of the capacity side than the Qwest market. So a little more aggressive there in a few markets where we've built up build outs and potential build outs in some markets. Regarding IPTV, as I mentioned earlier, we having good results in our markets overall. For competitive reasons, we won't talk too much but I do think we'll be looking to roll, to begin build out in at least 1 Qwest market by year-end, buildout IPTV product, roll out sometime next year and that's kind of our view and again, to a great extent, success based in we'll see success in the CenturyLink markets that we have in the first build out in Qwest, we see synergy success. There is demand in the market. There's no question the markets are going product. We think it competes well with cable actually our customers on our surveyed to it's a better product than what cable has in most cases. So we're confident that it's just a matter of significant situations plant conditions, loop shortening opportunities as far as the economics of building out in the Qwest markets.

componenttext: Okay. And then if I could follow-up the Phil's question on the Qwest high-speed Internet churn, I guess it just didn't make entire sense. I understand you had good inwards, but you're seeing churn from these stand-alone broadband customers. What would cause them to churn as you guys focus more on bundles? Did you try and raise pricing on the stand-alone broadband to encourage them to move to bundles and that's what caused them to leave or is there something else the caused that churn to pick up there?

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: No. If you just look at your churn, your profile of your high-speed customer, it's a customer that has another product, say, a double player, triple play or a stand-alone customer. Your stand-alone customers to stay have a higher churn, 23 basis points hi
componenttext: No. If you just look at your churn, your profile of your high-speed customer, it's a customer that has another product, say, a double player, triple play or a stand-alone customer. Your stand-alone customers to stay have a higher churn, 23 basis points higher, and so therefore, could give you a higher mix of your stand-alone, you're going to have more churn. So our objective is to take the stand-alone customers who are good customers. They just have higher churn, right, than a bundled customer and try to get them into a bundle. But we have not done any price increase or such.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2011

componenttext: We're not going to give you the percent, but yes, it was prior higher stand-alone sales prior to close, and it does have higher churns. So as glen said earlier, our inwards this second quarter were strong. It was more of a churn issue and the churn issue was caused by a higher mix of stand-alone than we anticipated.

componenttext: As well as promotions rolling off as well. That's had something to do with it.

componenttext: Not really lowering prices on the inmates. One of the states required us to reduce and increased interest rates a bit.

componenttext: It's driven by less adds from a go forward standpoint, that is our objective, is to improve the bundle with voice or other products. But right now, or video, but right now, it's just less outs. The ins are still down year-over-year, but they are improving, but I wouldn't say a massive improvement there is really about the disconnects being less.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: First question I had was, can you talk a little bit about in the quarter, maybe how the Qwest assets did relative to the Century just in a little bit more depth and maybe a sense as you look at the revisions to guidance, it sounds like the access side was
componenttext: First question I had was, can you talk a little bit about in the quarter, maybe how the Qwest assets did relative to the Century just in a little bit more depth and maybe a sense as you look at the revisions to guidance, it sounds like the access side was more on the Qwest side? Is that true on the CPE front as well? And then the other question I just had was with regard to the questions that you're wrestling with in terms of finalizing the intangible amortization. Just as I think back through a series of mergers that we've got to observe over the course of time, it seems like that's been -- once the deal is closed and the books are closed, it's become a pretty final number. We haven't seen a lot of movement in with the companies have guided or produced once the deal is closed on an intangible basis. Is there some things that's different or unique about your circumstances with the way the Qwest acquisition was structured or the way the Savvis was structured that's creating a little bit more of that uncertainty or question over what the final numbers look like?

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, Mike, really, what we try to do is estimate the amount that would be allocated to customer base and the amortization to be pretty much in line with what we did with respect to the Embarq and the way to Embarq was allocated. And I guess what we've subs
componenttext: No, Mike, really, what we try to do is estimate the amount that would be allocated to customer base and the amortization to be pretty much in line with what we did with respect to the Embarq and the way to Embarq was allocated. And I guess what we've subsequently found out after getting the pressure and and everyone's going through their process is, it looks that the accounting profession will likely change their process somewhat because we've gone through and listed out a number of transactions that happened over the last 3 or 4 years and the amount allocated to the customer base seems to be increasing from about 10% or so of the purchase price that we used in the Embarq transaction to about 30% to 35% of the purchase price in more recent transactions. So I think that's basically what's happening there, so it's nothing structurally different about the Qwest transaction. I think it's just more or less a change, it seems like in the appraisers approach to valuing the customer base.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: I might talk a little bit about the synergy issue. We anticipate that we rolled out our talk about the operational synergy of $575 million. That was back in early part of 2010. Now over the past 12 months, Qwest took out a huge amount of costs down to bus
componenttext: I might talk a little bit about the synergy issue. We anticipate that we rolled out our talk about the operational synergy of $575 million. That was back in early part of 2010. Now over the past 12 months, Qwest took out a huge amount of costs down to business. But time, we were estimating our synergies. We're still saying we'll hit our targets but it's a tough one when they took out so much of what we had initially counted as synergies ourselves. They took it out of the business. So we still think we're confident we'll hit our synergy number, but they did a good job reducing costs in the last 12 months before we closed.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. And with respect to the revenue decline, Mike, the half of the decline a really better than half is related, or about half is really related to CPE. Most of that is in the BMG side, the segment that basically sells to larger business customers. So th
componenttext: Yes. And with respect to the revenue decline, Mike, the half of the decline a really better than half is related, or about half is really related to CPE. Most of that is in the BMG side, the segment that basically sells to larger business customers. So that's where most of that CPE revenue decline is occurring. The other legacy revenue declines are, there's not much difference between the amount that we are experiencing at the legacy CenturyLink and the legacy Qwest there. I'd say that's basically split pretty much equally.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2011

componenttext: And can you give us a recap of where you stand with the regulatory side, with the high cost, the federal U.S. sass, switched access and then your cost of access in terms of trying to understand what the implications of the reform proposal that you signed onto would mean for your financials over time?

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Mike, I'll start out. This is basically, we do support the plan. We don't think the status quo is good for us, plus or our customers. The communications environment is changing rapidly. The technology is and evolving customer demand. So we think this is a
componenttext: Mike, I'll start out. This is basically, we do support the plan. We don't think the status quo is good for us, plus or our customers. The communications environment is changing rapidly. The technology is and evolving customer demand. So we think this is a good plan. The plans have been rolled out. It's not perfect but it does represent a rational compromise proposal that we believe makes a significant strides towards reforming several critical elements that will ultimately be good for the consumers, and for the company and the marketplace. We'll make some meaningful short-term concessions, but ultimately they'll provide long-term stability and predictability related to conversation placements. The transitional develop into plan are aggressive but we believe it's early manageable for us and the first to settle steps reduce switch access could begin in January. It's true but there is a phase in approach and given the accelerating declines of intrastate switch access so we talked about that already, really for our guidance changing some. We view the transition really ultimately as being really needed as a stabilizer in minutes of use and in revenues going forward. Stewart, do you want to address any?

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2011

componenttext: Yes, and on the USF at switch access, I'd have to go pull that to be specific. But I think as I recall on a pro forma basis, USF and access was about 7% of total revenues and I think about 3% of that was USF from 4% access.

componenttext: So Mike, there's really no switch between our node reallocation between BMG and wholesale markets in terms of revenue. Basically, there were some -- we we're basically allocating customers to the BMG group and to the RMG group and there were some RMG pickup some of the BMG customers and some of the smaller customers, some of the state government customers that using the local model in the RMG group might be closer to. BMG picked up some of the larger enterprise customers that RMG had, legacy CenturyLink RMG. But we're basically doing that division similar to the way Qwest has done it in the past on a customer basis. with respect to wholesale, there's no real change there and no movement of customers from any segment to wholesale or from wholesale to the other segments.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2011

componenttext: In terms of data integration and the reason we're missing that, again, it's really most of it is on the BMG segment and really, most of it as far as we can tell and Chris can tell is really due to government spending slowing down on CPE which is what the data integration services primarily are, as well as just the smaller average deals that they've obtained, that they've sold this year. Again, the indication is that they've sold about the same number of as they have in the past, but the average size of each transaction seems to be small and experienced last year. Also, if you look at our guidance, BMG had a big fourth quarter last year in terms of data integration revenue, and again, we've scaled our guidance back because we really don't think we'll get to the same fourth quarter, again, one-time revenue associated with the data integration that Qwest had in the fourth quarter last year in the BMG group.

componenttext: I don't think it has anything to do with that. I think the indications are, it's just basically slower movement from the government and we're attributing some of it basically just the debt ceiling issue and basically the government's slow spending down to wait to see what transpired there.

componenttext: Yes. I'll just tell, Mike, obviously, I personally believe it's an amazing buyer right now would like the buyback. We are to by back or reducing our debt to $1.5 billion to $2 billion over the next 2 years and we'll just have to look at stock buybacks. We really don't plan to do anything before early next year as we take a look to progress this year, we are looking at, again, our buyback program, use of our free cash flow. But it's certainly a consideration for us with the stock price where it is now.

headline: CenturyLink, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you. In closing, CenturyLink, we believe, had a solid financial results for the quarter, improving top line revenue trends, strong cash flows. We are also pleased that close the Savvis acquisition, we're looking forward to make a solid progress inte
componenttext: Thank you. In closing, CenturyLink, we believe, had a solid financial results for the quarter, improving top line revenue trends, strong cash flows. We are also pleased that close the Savvis acquisition, we're looking forward to make a solid progress integrating Qwest and Savvis in the months ahead. The last few months have been truly transformational for CenturyLink and we believe we are well-positioned to provide customers innovative product and services they need. I'm confident we we'll continue to see solid growth in the months ahead and create long-term shareholder value. We appreciate your participation in our call today and we look forward to speaking with you again in the weeks and months ahead.
